Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Transit Network Disruption, Service Reliability, and Travel Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Major transit disruptions have become more frequent due to increasing maintenance needs for an aging infrastructure, system failures, and disasters. Both transportation agencies and travelers need better information to prepare for such events. Considering the significant public distress caused by such events, the objectives of this research are crucial to the well-being of our society. Understanding travelers' behavioral responses over time are essential to effective planning and management of multimodal transportation systems for infrastructure maintenance and disaster response. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will collect unique and perishible data on system performance and travel behavior before, during and after each of the 15 Metro service disruption events (the SafeTrack project) in the Washington D.C. metropolitan area scheduled between June 2016 and March 2017. The analysis will advance our understanding on the impact of major transit service disruptions on a multi-modal transportation system, yielding insights on how to optimize the planning and execution of maintenance events. The field of transportation systems analysis will benefit from the detailed travel behavior adjustment and system-level re-equilibration observations collected from this project. Mass transit may be the only option for many low-income or disadvantaged travelers, and this research will also reveal members of these groups respond to transit service disruptions.

The objectives of the research are to 1) collect unique system performance and travel behavior data sets before, during and after each of the 15 Metro service disruption events using state-of-the-art longitudinal behavior data collection methods; 2) test hypotheses on the impact of major transit service disruptions on a multi-modal transportation system; 3) advance understanding of human behavioral responses and system re-equilibration after such disruptions; and 4) systematically discover planning and operations strategies that can minimize the impact of major transit service shutdowns based on this improved understanding of travel behavior. This project will be the first comprehensive study on transit network disruption of this magnitude with complete before-and-after travel behavior and system performance data. Longitudinal travel behavior data produced from this project will also stimulate future research on transit network reliability, resiliency, and incident response. This project will fill a major gap in the literature on multi-modal, multi-dimensional travel behavioral responses to major transit network disruptions. This will also be a first research effort that explores the transportation system re-equilibration (or lack of it) after major transit network disruptions. Understanding how travelers respond to transit service disruptions is a critically theoretical prerequisite toward developing and implementing effective strategies (e.g., how to optimally deploy the reserved bus fleet) that minimize system impact and improve transit system reliability and resiliency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Between June 2016 and June 2017, the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA) either shut down or significantly reduced Metro rail transit services to accommodate 16 separate SafeTrack system maintenance projects. This provided a unique opportunity to improve our knowledge of travelers’ behavioral responses to major transit system disruptions and the consequent system mobility, reliability and resiliency impact. Key objectives of this research are to 1) collect unique system performance and travel behavior datasets before, during and after each of the 16 Metro service disruption events using state-of-the-art data collection methods; 2) test hypotheses on the impact of major transit service disruptions on a multi-modal transportation system; 3) advance our understanding of human behavioral responses, decision-making by travelers, and system re-equilibration after such disruptions; and 4) systematically discover planning and operations strategies that can minimize the impact of major transit service shutdowns based on this improved understanding of travel behavior.

To achieve these objectives, the research team conducted a pre-event travel survey before each Metro service disruption among affected Metro riders, which was followed by a recall survey on actual travel adjustments (change of destination, mode, departure time, etc.) during and after the disruption. Supplementary data such as Metro ridership, Metro operations, changes on regional bus services, usage of rideshare and bike share programs, and traffic volume and travel speed on the regional transportation network were also collected to support the evaluation. The research team has also developed an algorithm to estimate the level of service characteristics (travel time, distance, and cost) for commuting trips based on emerging online transportation information services such as Google Application Programming Interface (API), API by E-hailing services (Uber, Lyft, etc.), and API offered by transit operators. This method is the first in the literature to estimate travel mode choices during major network disruption based on revealed choices and Level Of Service characteristics in real time on a large network. It overcomes a major data barrier in estimating travel demand models using revealed preference data on a large network and for a large sample size. It demonstrated a new method to improve travel demand model development by leveraging many emerging data sources and could be valuable for transportation management agencies.

This research found that the impact of a major transit network disruption such as the Washington Metro SafeTrack on surface traffic network was moderate. Both the predictions based on traffic simulation model and the observations based on INRIX data showed that travel time on major corridors serving the same areas as the affected metro services increased less than 3%, which falls within the band of day-to-day travel time variations commonly observed during the similar time of the year. However, the SafeTrack project did affect travelers using the metro services. The most common reactions included changing departure time (30.7%) and changing mode (29.9%), while fewer respondents chose to cancel trips (11.5%) and change destination (6.4%). 16.4% of respondents stated that they did not make any changes during the SafeTrack project. This is less than the percentage of respondents (30.4%) who stated that they did not plan to make any changes before the project started. Only 81.8% of survey respondents went back to the metro even after the services have been restored. These findings suggested that the SafeTrack projected did significantly affect individual travel behavior and the impact may last for a while.

By integrating survey responses with the online transportation information services, the research team was able to estimate the LOS characteristics of trips travelers took during the SafeTrack project for all modes travelers could potentially take (not limited to the mode they actually took). These data allowed the research team to develop a mode choice model under major travel network disruptions on a large and multi-modal transportation network using revealed preference data. The estimated Nested Logit model showed that travel time, travel cost, age, and gender had a significant impact on mode choices. Travelers would prefer shorter travel time and lower travel costs, with an estimated value of time at about $30/hour. Older travelers were less likely to use non-motorized modes and male travelers were more likely to use non-motorized modes.

Understanding how travelers respond to transit service disruptions is a critically theoretical prerequisite toward developing and implementing effective strategies (e.g., how to optimally deploy the reserved bus fleet) that minimize system impact and improve transit system reliability. Major transit infrastructure maintenance and the resulting service disruptions will become more frequent across the U.S. and internationally, as agencies form strategies to modernize their vast aging transit systems. This research offered important empirical evidence on the impact of such disruptions on regional traffic network and individual travel choices. The data integration method and the quantitative model developed in this study will help transportation agencies and the public to better prepare for future service disruption events.
